bibl.title: Letter from Lewis J. Moorman to Philip Showalter Hench, March 22, 1946

div1.p: Moorman thanks Hench for his comments regarding his manuscript on the yellow fever experiments. He intends to make it clear that the doctors did not want to become entangled with red tape and delay.

div1.head: Letter from Lewis J. Moorman to Philip Showalter Hench, March 22, 1946
div1.opener:
Farm Sanatorium
50th and North Walker
L. J. Moorman, Med. Dir.
Office
304 Osler Building
1200 North Walker
Lambert
LEWIS J. MOORMAN, M. D.
OKLAHOMA CITY 3, OKLAHOMA
March 22, 1946
Dr. Phillip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Please accept my thanks for your interesting
comments re: the manuscript dealing with the yellow fever
episode. Also, may I thank you for the suggestions which may
lead to some alteration in order to make clear the fact that
I am not implying that congress withheld cooperation, but
that the doctors concerned feared to become entangled with
the red tape and the necessary delays. Whether or not the
manuscript is accepted for publication, I will see that you
have a copy.

In closing, may I thank you for the reprint which
came to my desk yesterday. I am filing it for future
reference. With all good wishes, I am
div1.closer: Very sincerely, Lewis J. Moorman, M.D. LJM:rjl
